article.title: pansy
article.p:
pansy
, any of several popular cultivated violets of the genus
Viola
in the family Violaceae. Pansies have been grown for so long a period under such diverse conditions and in such a variety of forms that their origin is uncertain. The numerous forms, with their striking variations in colour, are the product of
domestication
.

h1.title: Physical description
h1.p:
The pansy is an
annual
or a short-lived
perennial
and grows about 15 to 30 cm (6 to 12 inches) tall. Heart-shaped or rounded
leaves
sprout from the base, and oblong or oval leaves grow from the stems. The plant’s velvety
flowers
, which usually occur in combinations of blue, yellow, and white, are about 2.5 to 5 cm (1 to 2 inches) across and have five petals. The garden pansy grows best in rich soil in a damp, cool climate.

h1.title: Major species
h1.p:
garden pansy
Garden pansy (
Viola ×wittrockiana
).
© www555www/stock.adobe.com
The garden pansy (
Viola ×wittrockiana
) is a hybrid, one of whose parents is
V. tricolor
, which is a weed of European grainfields, the other parents being
V. lutea
and
V. altaica
. The tufted pansy, or horned viola (
V. cornuta
), is the parent of numerous forms of bedding pansies.

wild pansy
Wild pansy (
Viola tricolor
).
Kitty Kohout/Root Resources
The wild pansy (
V. tricolor
), also known as Johnny-jump-up, heartsease, and love-in-idleness, has been widely naturalized in North America. The flowers of this form are usually purple and yellow and less than 2 cm (0.8 inch) across.
